questions.text: A 12-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department because of a high-grade fever for 3 days. He has been lethargic and not feeding well during this period. He cries incessantly while passing urine. There is no family history of serious illness. He was delivered at 37 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was complicated by mild oligohydramnios. His immunizations are up to date. He is at the 35th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 165/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 55/30 mm Hg. Examination shows open anterior and posterior fontanelles. There is a midline lower abdominal mass extending 2–3 cm above the symphysis. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The child is diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy is begun. This patient will most likely benefit the most from which of the following interventions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Meatotomy is the preferred treatment option for meatal stenosis. Congenital meatal stenosis, which is caused by failed regression of the distal urethral membrane, may manifest in neonates with signs of urinary obstruction, such as this patient's palpable bladder on physical examination and his history of oligohydramnios. However, meatal stenosis is most frequently acquired (e.g., secondary to circumcision) rather than congenital, making this diagnosis less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Diverticulum excision with urethral reconstruction is used in the treatment of urethral diverticula. Even though urethral diverticula may rarely manifest with urinary retention, it more frequently manifests with dribbling, dysuria, and dyspareunia in adult women or as a complication of urethral surgery (e.g., correction of hypospadias).

C) INCORRECT:

Subureteric transurethral injection of dextranomer is indicated in the treatment of patients with severe vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). While VUR typically manifests with febrile urinary tract infection, which is seen in this patient, VUR does not usually cause bladder outflow obstruction (as indicated by the history of oligohydramnios and palpable bladder in this patient).

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical reimplantation of the ureters is indicated in patients with severe vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). Neonates with VUR typically present with febrile urinary tract infections, as seen in this patient. However, since VUR does not cause bladder outflow obstruction, the history of oligohydramnios and the finding of a palpable bladder on physical examination are not consistent with this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Vesicostomy is the second-line treatment in patients with posterior urethral valves. It is indicated if the preferred treatment is not possible, e.g., due to technical issues or in early preterm infants. While this neonate likely does have posterior urethral valves, he was born at term and should receive the first-line treatment.

F) CORRECT:

This patient presents with urosepsis, a palpable bladder, and a history of oligohydramnios, all of which are features of lower urinary tract obstruction (UTO) due to posterior urethral valves (PUV). A PUV is present in about 1/4,000 live births, making it the most common cause of UTO in newborn boys. The treatment of choice is cystoscopy with primary valve ablation.

The presence of PUV can be detected via prenatal ultrasound, which usually shows a distended bladder, bilateral hydroureters, hydronephrosis with marked vesicoureteral reflux, and megaureter, as well as oligohydramnios. In severe cases, the deficiency of amniotic fluid may lead to the development of the Potter sequence: pulmonary hypoplasia, craniofacial abnormalities, and limb anomalies.
questions.hint: This patient's midline lower abdominal mass that extends 2–3 cm above the symphysis is most likely the distended bladder.

questions.text: A 2500-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 35 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 78%. Examination in the delivery room shows that the newborn's skin appears blue. He has a weak cry with irregular breathing and gasping. The nose is flat with prominent bilateral epicanthal folds. The ears are low-set with broad auricles. The lower jaw is abnormally displaced backwards. The right lower limb appears shorter than the left lower limb with displaced right great toe. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral dilatation of the renal pelvis and ureters. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Voiding cystourethrogram is the test of choice to diagnose posterior urethral valves (PUV), which is the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction (UTO) in newborn males. Lower UTO, indicated by the presence of bilateral hydronephrosis on renal ultrasound, results in reduced urine output and oligohydramnios. The decreased amount of amniotic fluid leads to the development of Potter sequence. Moreover, oligohydramnios can affect the development of the fetal lung resulting in lung hypoplasia, which is the most likely cause of this patient's cyanosis and hypoxia.

Once the vital functions have been stabilized, temporary insertion of a urinary catheter can relieve the UTO and allow for correction of possible electrolyte imbalances. Definitive treatment of PUV is either primary valve ablation during cystoscopy (first-line) or vesicostomy (in preterm boys or if ablation is not possible).

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to confirm congenital heart defects. Cyanotic heart defects may present shortly after birth with respiratory distress and cyanosis. Some of these defects are associated with certain genetic/chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot or persistent truncus arteriosus with DiGeorge syndrome), which often present with craniofacial anomalies. However, the patient's hydronephrosis and limb abnormalities cannot be explained by this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping confirms chromosomal abnormalities, which are frequently associated with dysmorphic facial and limb abnormalities. Low-set ears and retrognathia can be seen in patients with Edwards syndrome. A flattened nose and epicanthus are features of Down syndrome. The combination of oligohydramnios, hydronephrosis, and respiratory distress in the newborn period would not be typical for a chromosomal aberration. Certain causes of Potter sequence are associated with chromosomal aberrations. However, these abnormalities usually account for bilateral renal agenesis, whereas this infant's ultrasound confirms the presence of two kidneys.

D) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are essential in a newborn with respiratory distress to rule out sepsis. Early-onset sepsis (≤ 72 hours after birth) is often due to chorioamnionitis or bacterial colonization of the maternal genital tract (e.g., with group B Streptococcus). While the symptoms of neonatal sepsis may be nonspecific, infants with neonatal pneumonia typically present with dyspnea and decreased breath sounds, as seen in the vignette. However, neonatal pneumonia would not explain hydronephrosis and dysmorphia in this child.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with Potter sequence, chest x-ray may reveal pulmonary hypoplasia as the cause of this patient's respiratory distress, but it does not reveal the underlying mechanism of the condition. Chest x-ray is used, however, for diagnosing infant respiratory distress syndrome (IRDS) and meconium aspiration. IRDS manifests most frequently in preterm infants, usually immediately after birth, with signs of increased breathing effort, hypoxia, cyanosis, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation. However, the additional clinical features seen in this neonate (e.g., craniofacial dysmorphism, limb abnormalities, and hydronephrosis) could not be explained by this diagnosis. Meconium aspiration syndrome manifests with respiratory distress or unresponsiveness usually in postterm rather than preterm infants. Furthermore, the absence of a green amniotic fluid makes the diagnosis unlikely in this patient.
questions.hint: This newborn has features suggestive of Potter sequence: respiratory distress, Potter facies, limb anomalies, and a pregnancy complicated by oligohydramnios.

questions.text: A male newborn is born at 37 weeks' gestation after spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother had no prenatal care. Physical examination shows a urethral opening on the dorsal aspect of the penis, 4 mm proximal to the glans. There is a 3-cm defect in the midline abdominal wall superior to the pubic symphysis with exposure of moist, erythematous mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Incomplete union of the labioscrotal swellings
Failed fusion of the urethral folds

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Persistence of the urogenital membrane is associated with the development of posterior urethral valves, which, due to the fetus's inability to properly excrete urine, can lead to oligohydramnios. Severe oligohydramnios results in Potter sequence, which consists of craniofacial abnormalities, clubbed feet, and pulmonary hypoplasia. Posterior urethral valves can cause bladder dysfunction but are not associated with epispadias or bladder exstrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Incomplete union of the labioscrotal swellings causes a bifid scrotum, which manifests with a midline cleft in the scrotum. Bifid scrotum is associated with hypospadias, not epispadias or bladder exstrophy. Any atypical genitalia findings in a newborn should prompt evaluation for a disorder of sexual development such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia or androgen insensitivity syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Misdirected growth of the genital tubercle in the posterior (rather than superior) direction during the 5th week of gestation results in epispadias. It is very rare for bladder exstrophy to occur without epispadias, but epispadias can occur without bladder exstrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

If the gubernaculum does not involute, the testes may not descend properly into the scrotum, which results in cryptorchidism. This condition is not associated with epispadias or bladder exstrophy.

E) INCORRECT:

Failed fusion of the urethral folds during the 17th week of gestation results in hypospadias, which manifests with a urethral opening proximal to the glans on the ventral aspect of the penis. Hypospadias is associated with inguinal hernias and cryptorchidism, not bladder exstrophy.
questions.hint: This male newborn has epispadias, a condition that manifests with a urethral opening on the dorsal aspect of the penis. Epispadias is often associated with bladder exstrophy, which causes herniation of bladder mucosa through the lower midline abdominal wall, as seen in this patient.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 3 days
Sex assigned at birth: M
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: the patient is brought by his parents because they would like their child to be circumcised
History of Present Illness:

uneventful home birth at 39 weeks' gestation; Apgar scores 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively 
infant received all routine newborn care 
parents noticed the patient's urine sprays downward when changing his diaper

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

mother age 41 years with type 2 diabetes mellitus 
father age 43 years and sister age 2 years: alive with no chronic conditions

Psychosocial History:

lives with parents and sister
father smokes at home

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.9°C(98.4°F)
148/min
45/min
64/41 mm Hg
–

51 cm(20 in)

3.4 kg(7.5 lb)
–



Appearance: no acute distress; no facial dysmorphia
Skin: no rashes
HEENT: no ocular abnormalities; oral mucosa pink and moist; thyroid gland is normal in size
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm, normal S1 and S2, no murmurs
Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver edge palpated 2 cm below the costal margin; spleen is not palpable
Extremities: no edema or tenderness
Neurologic: alert; no abnormalities
Pelvic: normal penile length with moderate curvature; normal glans size; additional opening 3 mm below a blind-ending external urethral meatus on the ventral glans penis; incomplete closure of the foreskin, leaving the tip of the penis exposed; both testes are descended 


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Plan for surgical repair in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypospadias is not a medical emergency that warrants urgent surgical correction. Furthermore, in patients with accompanying chordee, surgical straightening of the curvature is important for successful correction of hypospadias and is usually performed along with urethroplasty. Penile straightening ensures proper sexual function.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with hypospadias and significant deflection of the urinary stream should be treated operatively between 6–12 months of age. Surgical repair includes urethroplasty, to correct the direction of the urethra, and orthoplasty, to correct the curvature of the penis, which is essential for the successful treatment of hypospadias. Newborn circumcision is generally not recommended in patients with hypospadias because the foreskin might be needed for a skin flap during urethroplasty. Hypospadias is associated with increased maternal age, maternal diabetes mellitus, and prenatal exposure to smoking.

C) INCORRECT:

Preoperative hormonal therapy with testosterone can be used to stimulate penile growth in patients with hypospadias who have a microphallus (penile length < 2 standard deviations below the mean length for age). As this patient has standard hypospadias and a normal penis size, testosterone therapy is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Elective circumcision is commonly performed during the neonatal period for social or religious purposes, but circumcision is generally not recommended in individuals with hypospadias because it can negatively affect outcomes. Medical indications for circumcision include refractory balanoposthitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and pathological phimosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping is not routinely indicated for a patient with hypospadias. It is only performed if the patient has congenital anomalies affecting multiple systems (e.g., cleft lip, congenital heart defect, imperforate anus), or if there are features that raise concern for a disorder of sex development such as severe hypospadias (e.g., urethral meatus displaced to the scrotum or perineum) and cryptorchidism. As this patient has isolated standard hypospadias, karyotyping is not required.
questions.hint: This patient's ectopic external urethral meatus, chordee (i.e., penile curvature), dorsal hood (i.e., incomplete closure of the foreskin), and normal penile length and glans size make standard hypospadias the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States reports a 3-day history of dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and low-grade fever. He was born preterm and has a history of urinary tract infections that started at age 6 and occurred, on average, one to two times per year.
On examination, his blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg, his heart rate is 88 beats per minute, and his temperature is 37.9°C. Other than mild suprapubic tenderness to palpation, his physical examination is unremarkable.
His urine dipstick shows 2+ leukocyte esterase, positive nitrites, and 1+ protein.
Given this patient’s history, which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely underlying cause of his recurrent urinary tract infections?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bladder diverticulum is usually asymptomatic, but patients may present with difficulty voiding and uncomplicated urinary tract infections.

B) CORRECT:

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), the most common identifiable cause of urinary tract infections in young children, occurs when urine passes from the bladder into the upper urinary tract due to incompetence of the ureterovesical junction during bladder contraction. VUR occurs more often in girls, but any child with a urinary tract infection should be evaluated. Risk factors for VUR include a family history of genitourinary tract abnormalities. VUR is associated with pyelonephritis, renal scarring, and secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Early evaluation with voiding cystourethrogram and urology referral for surgical management is warranted.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of childhood-onset recurrent urinary tract infections in a young man is vesicoureteral reflux.

C) INCORRECT:

Atypical organisms such as Ureaplasma, Chlamydia, and Mycoplasma are sexually transmitted and can cause recurrent urinary tract infections in young adults, but they do not typically cause recurrent childhood urinary tract infections and pyelonephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with chronic granulomatous disease suffer from recurrent bouts of infection because of the diminished capacity of the immune system. The characteristic infections include pneumonia, abscesses, bacteremia, and suppurative arthritis, but not urinary tract infections in isolation.

E) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic patients with immunoglobulin A deficiency have a history significant for recurrent otitis media, sinusitis, bronchitis, pneumonia, and gastrointestinal tract infections.

questions.text: Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for a male infant who is being evaluated in the newborn nursery in preparation for circumcision and is found to have a generous fat pad requiring retraction, a 2.5-cm penis, and midshaft hypospadias?

choices.text: Defer outpatient circumcision until the fat pad recedes
Defer outpatient circumcision until the penis is at least 3 cm
Refer to urology for surgical evaluation
Proceed with circumcision in the nursery
Send karyotype to evaluate for ambiguous genitalia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of a generous fat pad requiring retraction is a relative contraindication for circumcision in the nursery. It is usually recommended that circumcision be deferred until the full penis is exposed at all times. This promotes full healing of the circumcision with reduced risk for the formation of adhesions.

B) INCORRECT:

In the absence of contraindications, circumcisions can typically proceed if the penis is at least 2 cm in length. Deferral of circumcision until the penis is at least 3 cm is not necessary. In this patient, the circumcision is not being deferred so that the penis can grow but rather to allow for surgical evaluation of the moderate hypospadias.

C) CORRECT:

Hypospadias can be classified as mild, moderate, or severe. Mild hypospadias is usually not seen until a circumcision is started and is described as subcoronal with an intact prepuce. Studies have shown the circumcision can be completed in the setting of mild hypospadias with a symmetric foreskin without affecting future corrective surgery. Midshaft (moderate) and scrotal or perineal (severe) hypospadias, however, require more significant surgical repair, and circumcision should not be performed until such repair is complete. Given the risk for urine flow being affected, the most important intervention for this patient at this time would be to consult urology for surgical evaluation.

Key learning point: A circumcision can be performed in the presence of hypospadias as long as there is an intact prepuce.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has moderate hypospadias, which is a contraindication to bedside circumcision in the nursery.

E) INCORRECT:

Checking a karyotype to better clarify ambiguous genitalia would be warranted if a patient had unclear anatomy or bilateral cryptorchidism. This patient's penis appears normal, with the exception of the hypospadias, which is not sufficient to diagnose ambiguous genitalia.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy presents to establish care after moving from another state. He has a history of posterior urethral valves that were suspected on antenatal ultrasound, confirmed on postnatal voiding cystourethrography, and treated with ablation shortly after birth. Since then, he has undergone renal-bladder ultrasounds that have demonstrated good corticomedullary differentiation, and his serum creatinine level has been stable at 0.7 mg/dL (reference range, 0.3–0.5). He is not yet toilet trained and has no known urinary tract infections.
His height and weight are at the 50th percentile for his age. He has a temperature of 37.0°C, a heart rate of 95 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/50 mm Hg. His physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following additional tests is most appropriate for long-term monitoring of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A 24-hour urine collection may be used in kidney disease to quantify proteinuria or to assess for risk of stone formation, but it is not indicated in this case. This is rarely required in children, in whom spot urine samples can be used to screen for proteinuria.

B) CORRECT:

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are the most common cause of neonatal lower urinary tract obstruction in boys, with an estimated incidence of 1 in 3000 to 1 in 8000 patients. Most cases are suspected on prenatal ultrasound and confirmed postnatally on voiding cystourethrography (VCUG). Treatment typically consists of endoscopic transurethral ablation.

The major complications of endoscopic transurethral ablation are stricture formation and urinary incontinence.

Postablation management should include monitoring of both renal and bladder function. Studies have shown that serum creatinine levels <1.0 mg/dL in the first year of life are predictive of a favorable outcome. Nevertheless, about one-third of patients with PUV have renal insufficiency before adulthood. Early diagnosis of abnormal voiding dynamics is crucial to preserving native renal function and protecting any future transplant.

Up to 75% of patients with PUVs have persistent bladder dysfunction in childhood. Urodynamic studies can reveal a wide range of pathologies, including a damaged external sphincter, high detrusor voiding pressures, persistent bladder-neck obstruction, and noncompliant bladder. A patient’s urodynamic pattern may evolve over time, so ongoing follow-up is required.

Key learning point: Given that most children with posterior urethral valves have persistent bladder dysfunction after valve ablation, postablation management should include urodynamic studies.

C) INCORRECT:

Given that both the renal ultrasound and serial creatinine values in this patient suggest that the renal function is largely preserved, there is no indication for routine screening of serum potassium levels.

D) INCORRECT:

A radionuclide cystogram is a lower-radiation alternative to a VCUG used to follow patients with vesicoureteral reflux.

E) INCORRECT:

Although VCUG is a key element in the diagnosis of posterior urethral valves and should be repeated shortly after ablation, it is not required in this patient now, 3 years after the ablation. VCUG has the potential to show some filling or voiding abnormalities but is less sensitive than a urodynamic study.

questions.text: Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for a male infant who is being evaluated in the newborn nursery in preparation for circumcision and is found to have a generous fat pad requiring retraction, a 2.5-cm penis, and midshaft hypospadias?

choices.text: Defer outpatient circumcision until the fat pad recedes
Defer outpatient circumcision until the penis is at least 3 cm
Refer to urology for surgical evaluation
Proceed with circumcision in the nursery
Send karyotype to evaluate for ambiguous genitalia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of a generous fat pad requiring retraction is a relative contraindication for circumcision in the nursery. It is usually recommended that circumcision be deferred until the full penis is exposed at all times. This promotes full healing of the circumcision with reduced risk for the formation of adhesions.

B) INCORRECT:

In the absence of contraindications, circumcisions can typically proceed if the penis is at least 2 cm in length. Deferral of circumcision until the penis is at least 3 cm is not necessary. In this patient, the circumcision is not being deferred so that the penis can grow but rather to allow for surgical evaluation of the moderate hypospadias.

C) CORRECT:

Hypospadias can be classified as mild, moderate, or severe. Mild hypospadias is usually not seen until a circumcision is started and is described as subcoronal with an intact prepuce. Studies have shown the circumcision can be completed in the setting of mild hypospadias with a symmetric foreskin without affecting future corrective surgery. Midshaft (moderate) and scrotal or perineal (severe) hypospadias, however, require more significant surgical repair, and circumcision should not be performed until such repair is complete. Given the risk for urine flow being affected, the most important intervention for this patient at this time would be to consult urology for surgical evaluation.

Key learning point: A circumcision can be performed in the presence of hypospadias as long as there is an intact prepuce.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has moderate hypospadias, which is a contraindication to bedside circumcision in the nursery.

E) INCORRECT:

Checking a karyotype to better clarify ambiguous genitalia would be warranted if a patient had unclear anatomy or bilateral cryptorchidism. This patient's penis appears normal, with the exception of the hypospadias, which is not sufficient to diagnose ambiguous genitalia.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old male newborn is evaluated for minimal urine output since birth in the Neonatal Unit. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios noted on a late second-trimester ultrasound. The infant's mother reports that he has not had a forceful urinary stream, and his diaper remains minimally wet. There is no gross hematuria or visible abnormality of the external genitalia. On examination, the infant appears somewhat lethargic. Abdominal palpation reveals a midline mass consistent with a distended bladder (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
140 μmol/L
27 - 88 μmol/L


Blood urea nitrogen
10 mmol/L
1.8 - 6.4 mmol/L



Renal ultrasound: Bilateral hydronephrosis
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurogenic bladder can cause urinary retention and hydronephrosis due to impaired bladder innervation. However, it is usually associated with neurological deficits or spinal abnormalities, which are absent here. The history of oligohydramnios suggests an obstructive process rather than a neurologic etiology.

B) CORRECT:

Posterior urethral valves manifest in male neonates with a weak urinary stream due to obstruction in the lower urinary tract. Oligohydramnios during pregnancy suggests reduced fetal urine production, a consequence of urinary tract obstruction. The palpable midline abdominal mass indicates a distended bladder, while renal ultrasound shows bilateral hydronephrosis, confirming upstream urinary tract dilation. Elevated serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels indicate impaired renal function from chronic back pressure. This condition occurs exclusively in male infants due to abnormal membranous folds in the posterior urethra.

Key learning point: Posterior urethral valves are the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male infants, leading to bilateral hydronephrosis and bladder distension.

C) INCORRECT:

Bladder exstrophy involves an exposed bladder mucosa and associated pelvic and genital abnormalities, which are not present here. The intact, distended bladder and minimal urine output suggest urinary retention due to obstruction, not continuous leakage typical of bladder exstrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Ureteropelvic junction obstruction typically causes unilateral hydronephrosis and does not lead to bladder distension, as the obstruction is above the bladder. The palpable midline mass and bilateral hydronephrosis suggest an obstruction at or distal to the bladder outlet.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old boy is noted to have his urethral opening on the ventral side of the glans, with a hooded foreskin. He is feeding well and has passed meconium. There is no family history of genital anomalies. Physical examination is otherwise normal. Hemodynamic vitals are stable. His parents request routine circumcision prior to hospital discharge.
Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Perform chordee release and circumcise at the same time
Proceed with circumcision prior to discharge
Delay circumcision until further assessment by pediatric urology

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chordee release is reserved for significant ventral curvature, which is not mentioned here. Circumcision would remove tissue needed for hypospadias repair. The foreskin is crucial for reconstructive surgery, and no chordee is identified in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

In hypospadias, the foreskin is preserved for reconstructive surgery. Routine circumcision would remove tissue needed for surgical correction, compromising future urological management. Circumcision is inappropriate in the presence of hypospadias.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasonography is considered when there is suspicion of associated renal anomalies, typically in proximal hypospadias or ambiguous genitalia. Distal hypospadias, as seen here, is usually isolated and not associated with upper urinary tract abnormalities.

D) CORRECT:

Hypospadias is characterized by a urethral meatus on the ventral side of the penis and a hooded foreskin. The preputial tissue is often used in surgical repair to reconstruct the urethra. Circumcision before a detailed urologic evaluation could remove tissue needed for effective surgical correction. Pediatric urology assessment ensures individualized repair strategies based on the malformation's extent and potential future interventions.

Key learning point: Infants with hypospadias should not undergo circumcision as the foreskin may be needed for surgical repair of the urethra.

questions.text: A 2-day-old boy has a urethral orifice on the dorsum of his penis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chordee involves abnormal penile curvature, usually ventral, due to fibrous tissue tethering. It is often associated with hypospadias but does not involve misplacement of the urethral meatus. The dorsally positioned urethral opening in this neonate indicates a different defect.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypospadias is a congenital anomaly where the urethral meatus is located on the ventral aspect of the penis, often with penile curvature and a hooded dorsal foreskin. The clinical description of a dorsally located urethral orifice is inconsistent with hypospadias.

C) INCORRECT:

Posterior urethral valves involve obstructive membranous folds in the posterior urethra, leading to urinary outflow obstruction. The urethral meatus is typically normally positioned. The dorsally located urethral orifice described does not align with this condition.

D) CORRECT:

Epispadias is characterized by the urethral meatus located on the dorsal surface of the penis. This condition results from abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle during embryologic development, leading to incomplete formation of the ventral urethral tube. It is important to recognize epispadias as it can be associated with bladder exstrophy, necessitating a thorough evaluation of the lower abdominal wall and urinary tract.

Key learning point: Epispadias is characterized by the urethral opening on the dorsal surface of the penis, whereas hypospadias involves a ventral urethral opening.

questions.text: You are evaluating a male infant in the newborn nursery in preparation for circumcision. On examination, you note a generous fat pad requiring retraction, a 2.5-cm penis, and midshaft hypospadias. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Defer outpatient circumcision until the penis is at least 3 cm.
Proceed with circumcision in the nursery.
Defer outpatient circumcision until the fat pad recedes.
Send karyotype to evaluate for ambiguous genitalia.
Refer to urology for surgical evaluation.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the absence of contraindications, circumcisions can typically proceed if the penis is at least 2 cm in length. Deferral of circumcision until the penis is at least 3 cm is not necessary. In this patient, the circumcision is not being deferred so that the penis can grow but rather to allow for surgical evaluation of the moderate hypospadias.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has moderate hypospadias, which is a contraindication to bedside circumcision in the nursery.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of a generous fat pad requiring retraction is a relative contraindication for circumcision in the nursery. It is usually recommended that circumcision be deferred until the full penis is exposed at all times. This promotes full healing of the circumcision with reduced risk for the formation of adhesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Checking a karyotype to better clarify ambiguous genitalia would be warranted if a patient had unclear anatomy or bilateral cryptorchidism. This patient's penis appears normal, with the exception of the hypospadias, which is not sufficient to diagnose ambiguous genitalia.

E) CORRECT:

Hypospadias can be classified as mild, moderate, or severe. Mild hypospadias is usually not seen until a circumcision is started and is described as subcoronal with an intact prepuce. Studies have shown the circumcision can be completed in the setting of mild hypospadias with a symmetric foreskin without affecting future corrective surgery. Midshaft (moderate) and scrotal or perineal (severe) hypospadias, however, require more significant surgical repair, and circumcision should not be performed until such repair is complete. Given the risk for urine flow being affected, the most important intervention for this patient at this time would be to consult urology for surgical evaluation.

Key learning point: A circumcision can be performed in the presence of hypospadias as long as there is an intact prepuce.
